Fiona: "I-Is there something I can help you with?" She asks in a small voice, looking up from her drink. Her eyes are wide and innocent as she blushes at the stranger's approach.
Journalist: "Yes! Actually, I'm writing an article on machine-sabotage during WWII and I thought you might know something about it." He smiles, trying to put her at ease. "Do you?"
Fiona: "Oh, yes..." She blushes deeper and looks down again, fidgeting with her hands. "I'm a spy for the Allies, actually. It's not as glamorous as it sounds; most of my time is spent waiting to sabotage factories or listening on officers." She giggles nervously and looks up through her eyelashes "Anyway, I can tell you what you want to know!"
Journalist: "Great! Firstly, what are some results of machine-sabotage mentioned in 'Simple Sabotage'?"
Fiona: "Machines will overheat and require new parts or extensive repairs," Fiona begins, her voice soft but confident. She leans forward as she speaks, her cleavage nearly spilling out of her top, "and production will slow or stop entirely at strategic points."
Journalist: _I can't believe this_ he thinks, trying to focus on the conversation. "Now, what is one way to damage a press?"
Fiona: "You can put more material than it's adjusted for into the press," Fiona whispers, her eyes wide and innocent as she leans closer. "Such as two blanks instead of one." She smiles coyly, batting her eyelashes.
Journalist: "I see... What are some ways to sabotage machines?" He asks, trying not to look at Fiona's body.
Fiona: "You can put metal dust, filings, fine sand, ground glass, emery dust into lubrication systems; remove filters from oil and lubrication systems; punch holes in them." She leans back, her voice a whisper as she finishes.
Journalist: "Finally, how does sabotage affect machines and production?"
Fiona: "Sabotage slows or stops work entirely at strategic points in industrial processes," Fiona answers, looking up with a shy smile. She then leans forward again, her voice barely audible as she continues, "Now that you've got your information... would you like to get some tea?"

She smiles weakly and shrugs, looking down again. "I've learned a lot about machines though: how they can be worn out or broken. It's crucial to my job."

What are some results of machine-sabotage mentioned in 'Simple Sabotage'?
Machines will overheat and require new parts or extensive repairs, and production will slow or stop entirely at strategic points.

(6You can put a press punch out of order by putting in it more material than it is adjusted for—two blanks instead of one, for example. (7) Power-driven tools like pneumatic drills, riveters, and so on, are never efficient when dirty. Lubrication points and electric contacts can easily be fouled by normal accumulations of dirt or the insertion of foreign matter. (b) Oil and lubrication systems are not only vulnerable to easy sabotage, but are critical in every machine with moving parts. Sabotage of oil and lubrication will slow production or stop work entirely at strategic points in industrial processes. (1) Put metal dust or filings, fine sand, ground glass, emery dust (get it by pounding up an emery knife sharpener) and similar hard, gritty substances directly into lubrication systems. They will scour smooth surfaces, ruining pistons, cylinder walls, shafts, and bearings. They will overheat and stop motors which will need overhauling, new parts, and extensive repairs. Such materials, if they are used, should be introduced into lubrication systems past any filters which otherwise would strain them out. (2) You can cause wear on any machine by uncovering a filter system, poking a pencil or any other sharp object through the filter mesh, then covering it up again. Or, if you can dispose of it quickly, simply remove the filter.
Simple Sabotage, by the Office of Strategic Services, published 1944
